<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 347, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
0606/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 267, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Non- calculator  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[840, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 212, 601]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 728, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 73, 568, 89]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 106, 784, 123]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 154, 675, 171]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 202, 685, 219]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 247, 680, 274]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 294, 685, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 348, 656, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 368, 561, 401]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 444, 225, 460]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 435, 905, 476]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 483, 770, 523]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 555, 220, 570]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 552, 670, 592]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 630, 220, 645]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 628, 572, 710]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 740, 160, 755]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 738, 555, 789]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^2 A + \cos^2 A = 1 \\ \sec^2 A = 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cosec^2 A = 1 + \cot^2 A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 829, 241, 845]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 823, 577, 900]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[330, 72, 666, 89]]<|/det|>
<form>Calculators must not be used in this paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 104, 99, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 114, 855, 319]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 351, 697, 368]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y=\left| \mathrm{f}(x) \right|\), where f is a cubic polynomial.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 367, 529, 383]]<|/det|>
Find expressions for the two possible functions \(\mathrm{f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 383, 484, 399]]<|/det|>
Write each expression in fully factorised form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 648, 96]]<|/det|>
3 A circle with centre \(C\) has the equation \(x^{2}+y^{2}-10 x-4 y+24=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 110, 144, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 109, 604, 127]]<|/det|>
(a) Show that the line \(y=2 x-3\) is a tangent to this circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 310, 144, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 310, 790, 327]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that this tangent touches the circle at the point \(P\), find the coordinates of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 450, 144, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 448, 822, 466]]<|/det|>
(c) Find the equation of the circle which has its centre at \(P\) and passes through the origin.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 84, 99, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 84, 144, 101]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 304, 107]]<|/det|>
4 (a) Find \(\int_{0}^{\pi} \sin \theta \mathrm{d} \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 303, 144, 320]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 293, 730, 325]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that \(0<\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2}\), show that \(\frac{\sec \alpha}{\cot \alpha+\tan \alpha}\) can be written as \(\sin \alpha\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 796, 96]]<|/det|>
5 The polynomial p is such that \(\mathrm{p}(x)=3 x^{3}-7 x^{2}+a x+b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 108, 604, 127]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{p}^{\prime}(-1)=21\) and that \(x-2\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 141, 144, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 140, 367, 158]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 419, 144, 435]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 418, 718, 435]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence write \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) as a product of linear factors with integer coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 588, 144, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 586, 755, 604]]<|/det|>
(c) Using your values of \(a\) and \(b\), solve the equation \(3 \mathrm{e}^{6 y}-7 \mathrm{e}^{4 y}+a \mathrm{e}^{2 y}+b=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 77, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 918, 96]]<|/det|>
6 When \(\ln y\) is plotted against \(x^{3}\), a straight line passing through the points (2, 5) and \((-8,25)\) is obtained.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 110, 144, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 109, 317, 127]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(y\) in terms of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 402, 144, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 400, 422, 419]]<|/det|>
(b) Find the value of \(x\) when \(y=\mathrm{e}^{25}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 85, 99, 102]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 78, 883, 107]]<|/det|>
7 A geometric progression has a 4th term of \(\frac{8 k^{6}}{27}\) and a 6th term of \(\frac{32 k^{10}}{243}\), where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 115, 586, 133]]<|/det|>
The common ratio of this geometric progression is positive.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 149, 144, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 147, 918, 165]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the common ratio in terms of \(k\) and the value of the first term of this geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 520, 144, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 515, 908, 534]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that this geometric progression has a sum to infinity of 3 , find the possible values of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 87, 99, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 388, 107]]<|/det|>
8 It is given that \(y=\frac{\ln \left(3 x^{2}+16\right)}{x+2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 116, 144, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 114, 327, 139]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\) when \(x=0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 149, 601, 167]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in the form \(\ln p\), where \(p\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 536, 144, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 535, 880, 553]]<|/det|>
(b) Given that \(x\) increases from 0 to \(h\), where \(h\) is small, write down the approximate change in \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 75, 99, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 76, 646, 95]]<|/det|>
9 It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x)=2 \ln (3 x-4)\) ，for \(x>a\), and that \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\) exists.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 110, 144, 127]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 110, 421, 127]]<|/det|>
(a) Find the least possible value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 186, 144, 203]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 186, 465, 203]]<|/det|>
(b) For your value of \(a\), find the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 280, 144, 297]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 279, 551, 297]]<|/det|>
(c) For your value of \(a\), find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 387, 144, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 386, 594, 403]]<|/det|>
(d) It is given that the equation \(\mathrm{f}(x)=\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) has two roots.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 416, 770, 435]]<|/det|>
For your value of \(a\), sketch the graphs of \(y=\mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y=\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\) on the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 448, 300, 464]]<|/det|>
Label each graph.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 464, 529, 480]]<|/det|>
State the intercepts of each graph with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 481, 457, 496]]<|/det|>
State the equations of any asymptotes.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 510, 855, 790]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 71, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
10

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[319, 87, 678, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 275, 448, 291]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the shape \(O A B C D E F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 291, 292, 306]]<|/det|>
\(A O F\) is a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 306, 616, 322]]<|/det|>
\(O A B\) and \(O E F\) are sectors of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 322, 330, 337]]<|/det|>
Angle \(B O A=\text{angle } E O F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 346, 555, 371]]<|/det|>
\(O C D\) is a sector of a circle with centre \(O\) and radius \(\frac{4 r}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 382, 316, 397]]<|/det|>
Angle \(C O D\) is \(\theta\) radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 397, 641, 413]]<|/det|>
The point \(B\) lies on the line \(O C\) and the point \(E\) lies on the line \(O D\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 413, 425, 428]]<|/det|>
The line \(B E\) is parallel to the line \(A O F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 445, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 444, 645, 460]]<|/det|>
(a) Find, in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\), the area of the shaded region \(B C D E\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 84, 680, 255]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 275, 717, 307]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the shape from part (a) with region \(OABEF\) shaded. Find, in terms of \(r\) and \(\theta\), the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 88, 855, 300]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 316, 667, 336]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the triangle \(O A B\), where \(\overrightarrow{O A}=\mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{O B}=\mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 344, 485, 370]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) lies on \(O A\) such that \(\overrightarrow{O P}=\frac{3}{4} \overrightarrow{O A}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 373, 485, 400]]<|/det|>
The point \(Q\) lies on \(A B\) such that \(\overrightarrow{A Q}=\frac{1}{3} \overrightarrow{A B}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 408, 803, 445]]<|/det|>
The straight line through \(P\) and \(Q\) meets the straight line through \(O\) and \(B\) at the point \(R\). It is given that \(\overrightarrow{O R}=\lambda \mathbf{b}\) and \(\overrightarrow{P R}=\mu \overrightarrow{P Q}\), where \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 473, 144, 490]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 471, 413, 490]]<|/det|>
(a) Find \(\overrightarrow{O R}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 76, 426, 95]]<|/det|>
(b) Hence find the values of \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 725, 664, 742]]<|/det|>
Question 12 is printed on the next page.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 82, 116, 98]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 81, 682, 100]]<|/det|>
12 A curve is such that its gradient at the point \((x, y)\) is given by \(\left(5 x-2\right)^{\frac{1}{3}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 108, 463, 134]]<|/det|>
The curve passes through the point \(\left(2, \frac{32}{5}\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 144, 561, 161]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary point on the curve.
